list_definition.definition: to put more electrical power into a battery

list_ex_of_english: There is the recharging method, which is suitable in some pants of the country but not in others.
If we have a cold spell—one could start tonight—and if the fires burn low and cannot be recharged, public sympathy will dwindle.
The vehicles can go only 25 to 30 miles at the very most, and they must then come in and have their batteries recharged, which takes 12 hours.
The energy from the transformer core recharges the capacitor and supplies the load.
They can walk about the room avoiding obstacles, stroll round the garden, climb stairs, and feed themselves by automatically recharging six-volt accumulators from the light in the room.
In both years heavy winter rainfall had previously recharged the soil profile.
Most of the agriculture in the basin is sustained by groundwater, which is recharged with rainfall and riverflow.
However, no actual recharging of underground aquifers has been done.
